Edward is asleep then suddenly chuckles in his dream. Carter looks over, smiling knowingly before laying a postcard of the pyramids on his seat-back table. Starts to write.

Dear Chambers Family... We’re on our way to India now. He thinks a moment before looking out the window at the sun painted table of clouds below and the endless blue above. CARTER (V.O.) (CONT’D) I can’t tell you how much I miss you all. This is a gift that you’ve given me and everything I’ve seen and done has been through your eyes and with you in my heart. I’m taking all my pills and I honestly haven’t felt this good in years. I hope you’re well and looking after your mother... “I love you” doesn’t come close... Dad. He replaces the cap on the pen and leans his head back on the seat. Edward suddenly laughs out loud and Carter can’t help but chuckle as he closes his eyes to sleep.
Establishing.
The empress was the beloved wife of Shah Jehan, the fifth mughal emperor.
Carter and Edward walk past murals depicting the history of the monument.  87.
And though it was an arranged marriage, they were deeply in love and were inseparable until she died giving birth to their fourteenth child.
Fourteenth? That’s a lot of love.

They didn’t write the Kama Sutra for nothing... It took twenty-thousand volunteers twenty-two years to complete the structure in sixteen forty-eight. Every square foot designed by Shah Jehan himself. They stop at a tile mural of the empress.
So that’s true love.
Yeah. Edward reads Carter’s thoughts and quietly walks away leaving Carter to stare up at the mural.
Edward and Carter walk along the promenade beside the reflecting pools.
(trying to lighten the mood) You ever wonder why all the great historical monuments have to do with dead people?
Because they’re monuments. That’s what they’re for.
Yeah, but does being dead have to be a prerequisite? We can’t put up a tomb to the unborn soldier? “He would have died for his country if only his parents had been Catholic.”
You're losing your grip, aren't you?  88.
My family’s got this plot upstate. My parents are there. Cousins. Grandparents. The whole shebang. We even got a little monument of our own.
That where you want to end up?
I don’t know, I’m not sure they’d have me. I was a real pain in the ass when I was little. Hard to believe, I know. I dunno, it just seems so...colloquial.
I got it in my will. Want myself cremated and my ashes put in a can which they’1l bury somewhere with a view.
You mean an urn?
(shakes his head) I never liked the sound of it. “Urn.” Nope, an old can of Chock Full 0’ Nuts do me just fine.
Chock Full O--? The instant coffee?
Yup. Better coffee your money can’t buy.
I wouldn’t bet on that.
Ah yes, Kopi Luwak. You really dig that stuff, don’t you?
It's the best. What do you got against it?
Much too fancy for my taste. Simple pleasures my man, simple pleasures.  89.
Think I might get another tattoo.

Seen from a distance as it looms across the hilltops. A sound is heard in the far off distance. We can’t quite make it out, but it clearly doesn’t belong. ANOTHER SECTION OF THE WALL; closer now. The sound is heard again, a faint buzzing. AT THE BASE OF THE WALL; the buzzing is closer now. It’s joined by voices. ATOP THE WALL; plunging down a hillside before us then surging back up to our position. The buzzing is louder still and the voices appear to be singing.

Ah louie louie. Oh no. Say we gotta go. Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah. Said ah louie louie-- And suddenly a motorcycle bursts into view up the hillside. Edward clings to Carter’s back as they ride down the center of the wall, roaring by us then disappearing down the opposite hillside. VOICES (0.S.) (CONT’D) --whoa baby! Said we gotta go. Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah.

head_text.subj: AGED CELL BARS CLANGING AS A DOOR OPENS

text: Thomas stands with a disapproving look on his face as a guard leads Edward and Carter out of the cell. They’re dressed in filthy prison smocks with several weeks facial growth.
This is becoming epidemic.
(shuffling past him) Shower.  90.
(catching a whiff) Several.
Thomas waits with a towel while Edward showers. Carter is seen through the doorway, talking to his family on the phone in the living room. He’s yet to shower.
So what's the going rate for busting two Americans out of the Chinese clink?
Ain’t what it used to be.
That bad, huh?
You don’t want to know.
Actually, I do... Don’t I?

I’ve got your statements in my bag, but all told you're down to a couple million. Edward sticks his head through the shower door, halfway through shaving a new look that links his moustache to his sideburns.
You're joking me.
I never joke with Civil War heroes. Nice ink, by the way. Edward holds up his arms which are now covered in tattoos: a charging bull, the pyramids, etc.
Like ‘em? One for each item on the list.
How punk of you.  gl.
(after a beat) Thanks Thomas. Really, this is way above and beyond.
What are indentured servants for. Heads into...
Where Carter is just getting off the phone with his family.
We're flying to Tibet tonight then next stop home. Alright. I will... Alright... Goodbye. Hangs up the phone leaving the receiver smeared with grime. Thomas grabs a tissue and starts wiping it.
Did you tell them?
(nods ) My wife wants me tested for syphilis. She’1l be sticking needles in me for days when I get back.
You both seem in surprisingly good spirits considering...
I can’t explain it. I was telling Virginia. I feel...
Like a pigsty?
Young.
They say your mental disposition can have a tremendous impact on disease.
They can say what they want, just so long as he gets out of that shower soon. (MORE)
Say, let me ask you something Thomas. Is it Thomas or Tommy?
It's Matthew actually but he finds that too biblical... Thomas is fine.
As Edward emerges from the shower in a billowing cloud of steam.
She’s all yours. He wipes steam from the mirror to reveal his new look: Kojak meets Founding Father. Admires himself appropriately. Notices the lesions have faded on his head.
Hey, I said-- Sticks his head into the doorway to see Carter and Thomas whispering closely.
I do, but I’m not sure he’1l---
He’1l what?
Ever think about flying coach back to the States. You know, save some for a rainy day.
You chumps want to ride with your knees in your throat that’s your business... Shower’s up.
Thank the lord. Runs into the bathroom peeling his shirt off.
Where Edward and Carter take in the vista of hills rolling to the distant base of an impossibly enormous range of snow-covered mountains.  93.
Okay, it’s majestic.
That’s nothing. Twelve thousand tops.
What’s our mountain?
We're only going to base camp, but the peak’s about twenty nine thousand feet. Edward whistles.
Why so many fatalities?
Hmmm?
The air jockeys you were talking about. Ones that flew through the mountains.

The hump pilots. Well, first off you had the Jap zeros which could ambush you from anywhere as you flew through the valleys. That was the easy part... When the weather came in, which was always, they couldn’t choke off the supply runs, so they flew in the soup... Sonar was all they had back then. They used to try to ping off the mountains to plot their course between ‘em. Sometimes it worked... Sixty years and they’re still finding wreckage up there.
Your uncle?
Two years on the hump. Not a scratch on him.
Lucky guy.  94.

Maybe... When the storms rolled in and he couldn’t see an inch past the windshield, he used to close his eyes and focus until he couldn't hear the copilot or even the engines. He’d focus until everything fell away except the mountains passing on either side. He could hear them and, ‘til the day he passed, he swore they could hear him in return.
What did they sound like?
I asked him once. Near as he could figure- “Voice of god,” he said.
Wow, that’s... Is there anything in this world you don’t have a story about?
It's called reading. You should try it someday... Here, you can start with this. Slams a book in Edward's chest, Gandhi an Autobiography: The Story of My Experiments With Truth.
This some kind of yoga manual? Carter’s incredulous... Thomas comes up the steps. Edward tosses him the book.
Here. Read this for me.
So, shitty news or really shitty news?
The first one.
There’s a storm up there. They won’t fly until the weather clears.
(to Carter) Where’s your uncle when we need him.  95.
They expect it to clear?
Not for a month. Maybe two. That’s the really shitty news, in case you were wondering.
(disappointed) Next trip, huh? They know full well the remoteness of that possibility.
Definitely.
I guess it’s home then.
Maybe not.
The climbing season’s almost--
Everest isn’t the only majestic thing in the world.

Spewing enormous plumes of ash and lava into the night sky while rivers of molten rock stream from the crater. Carter, Edward, and Thomas stand atop a neighboring peak. Their faces hang in awe in the light of the eruption.

(to Carter) What, no story? Carter just shakes his head. Edward smiles and turns back to the show. The ground rumbles. They feel it. Thomas grabs Edward's hand to steady him. Edward does the same with Carter. SEEN FROM BEHIND; in silhouette, the three friends stand hand-in-hand at the beginning and end of the world.
Driving through the suburbs of New Jersey. Edward and Carter sit side by side in the back. Taking measure of what they’ve accomplished.
Thank you. Really.
Don’t be-- It’s nothing. It’s--
You're welcome, is what he’s trying to say.
Dead in a month my ass. They laugh and he looks out the window.
Hey Tommy, this isn’t Newark. You leave your compass back in Beijing? Thomas responds by putting up the divider between himself and the back seat. IN THE FRONT; Thomas exhales a deep breath.
One more stop.
Pulling up in front of a small ranch house.

Why are we-- Thomas, you off the methadone? What the hell’s-- Stops as he sees something through the window. It’s a woman. She’s standing in the window of the ranch house, pacing back and forth as she talks on the phone.
He kept tabs on her in case you ever wanted to--  97.
(livid) This was his idea?
No, it was mine. Took the whole flight to talk him into it.
Hey Carter, will you do something for me?
Name it. Edward opens the door and climbs out of the car and walks briskly away from the house. Carter watches him go...
(softly) Go fuck myself.
Edward walks briskly through pools of light from the street lamps. The limo pulls up and Carter jumps out.
This is what you want?
Telling someone a story doesn’t invite you to be a part of it. You had no right.
You're right, I didn’t. But she’s still there. Maybe you took the long way home but this is the road’s end.
Go away. Walks past him. Carter follows.
What are you so afraid of?
I'm not afraid of anything anymore. If you took a second to think it through you'd realize-- (stops walking) How did you see it? I knock on the door. She answers. (MORE)
She’s surprised and angry but I tell her how much I love her and missed her, and gradually, piece by piece, the ice starts to thaw?
It’s a start.
No, it’s an end. Because you left one thing out. You didn’t think-- How is it fair that I show up after all this time and inject myself back into her life when I could be dead in a week?
You just--
How do I tell her...without her believing that I’m only reaching out because I’m scared to die alone and didn’t care enough to consider what that would put her through.
Everyone’s afraid to die alone.
I’m not everyone.
Then you're kidding yourself.
If I am, I’m not the only one.
What’s that supposed--
What are you even doing here, Carter? You've got a family and a wife whose holding her heart in her hands while you’re flying around the world to “find the long way home.” Don’t you think she knows?
Knows what?
That you blame her for your lack of accomplishment.  99.
Don’t you dare--

That you say things like you “wouldn’t trade your life with them for anything”, but deep down you question yourself, so you say those things because you know they’re the right thing to say, rather than what you really feel.
You have no idea what I feel.

Maybe I don’t...but I know this. I love my daughter. If I didn’t I would be back there, knocking on her door. If you loved your wife, you wouldn’t have to go home because you’d have been there all along. He pulls out the Bucket List.
This is fun, Carter. That’s all it ever was. Then he tears it in half, then again, and lets the pieces flutter to the sidewalk. He sees Thomas standing by the limo.

Call me after you've taken him home. He walks off. Carter stands there, staring at the pavement... Music begins; Jeff Buckley’s “Hallelujah” as Thomas walks around the limo and opens the door for Carter. Carter nods and walks towards him and then stops and turns to look at the Bucket List as the pieces scatter

CARTER; walking up the steps to his house. He pauses at the door then opens it and carries his suitcase inside. EDWARD; hands in his pockets as he walks down a neighborhood street. The limo pulls up next to him and he climbs inside.  100. CARTER; in bed with his wife, each on their own side. Distance between them. . EDWARD; in his high-rise office sitting at his desk which faces the window with a view of the city shrouded in fog below. His hair is growing in again. He brings a coffee cup to his lips. It’s empty. CARTER; at the hospital getting a check-up. Holcomb comes in with test results. He’s amazed at Carter’s progress. Carter smiles as he buttons up his shirt. EDWARD; in his office kitchen. The box of Kopi Luwak is empty. He searches the cupboard finding only a can of instant. He puts the can back and walks out. CARTER; at the dinner table with his family. Virginia is saying grace. He’s watching her. She feels it and her eyes open. He reaches out and takes her hand. She smiles as their eyes hold each other and she continues to pray. EDWARD; shakes his head as he switches off the Yankee game. Moves to the bookshelf and browses until he removes a book on the Himalayas. VIRGINIA; waiting in the car for Carter. It’s autumn now and the windows are painted with frost. A finger appears, drawing letters on the windshield. WILL YOU MARRY ME? EDWARD; working out on the elliptical machine at the gym. It's late and the place is empty. CARTER AND VIRGINIA; standing in the center of a shopping mall, their friends and family around them as they renew their vows. EDWARD; stepping out of the shower. Wipes the steam from the mirror revealing his full head of hair and the journal of tattoos over his body. He touches the erupting volcano on his forearm. CARTER; home in bed staring at a small plastic bull. He puts it away as Virginia comes in, dressed in her nightgown. She climbs in bed and he reaches across and pulls her to him.
Happy second honeymoon.
Happy second honeymoon.  101. They kiss. His hands move to her hips under the covers.
Do you have any idea how long it’s been?
Do I want to know?
No, I don’t think you do.
I love you, ‘Gin.
I know you do.
It wasn’t that I ever stopped loving you so much as I forgot the reasons you loved me. (she touches his face) Remember that night, when I took you to the Bowl-O-Rama over on fourteenth street?
How do you think I could forget our first date? You wore that shirt with the stain on the front and your black shoes and brown belt.
And you wore a blue dress with little bows down the back.
(surprised) I can’t believe you--
I was so out of my league. I remember thinking, “What’s a girl looks like this doing slumming with a kid who's best shirt got a stain on the front?”
You weren’t worthy.
I’ve never been worthy of you.  102.

I was joking, baby. I knew that night after I got back. I told my mother I was your’s forever if you’d have me... Forever’s just getting started. They kiss again, more passionately until she pulls away and stands out of bed.
I got something for you. Wasn’t sure I'd need it.

Don’t be long now. She goes into the bathroom and closes the door halfway. We see her feet stepping out of her pajamas and into something black and lacy. When the door opens her hair is down and spilling over her shoulders and a thin, satin negligee.
Carter? The bed is empty. She walks around it.
So we’re playing games now? You think you can get me all riled up then-- She stops as she sees him face down on the floor, his hands twitching.
Carter! She turns him over to see his eyes are rolled back into his head as the seizure storms through him.
Roger! She finds his wallet on the bedside table and forces it between his teeth. Roger appears at the door--
What’s the--  103. He sees his father on the floor then runs for the phone. Rachel and Lee appear. Lee runs to help Virginia as Rachel stands in the doorway watching her father.
Edward and his date, AMERY, a pretty middle-aged woman sit at a table against the wall.
It’s Bruno’s specialty. It’s not on the menu.
That’s a lot of food.
I’m a bottomless pit. Besides, I’m in training.
Isn’t mountain climbing dangerous?
For someone my age? You can say it. She's interrupted by the MAITRE’D who walks briskly to the table.
I’m sorry Mister Cole. It’s your driver. He says it’s urgent. Edward turns to the front door where Thomas stands. His face says everything.
Edward emerges from the elevator and walks pointedly towards his old room. Passes Holcomb at the nurse’s station.
(walking after him) Edward.
When did this happen?  104.
It came out of nowhere but it’s his brain and the tumors are deep.
So you can operate?
Day after tomorrow.
And he'll be alright?
In his condition it’s not-- The odds aren’t what we’d like them to be. Edward sees there’s little hope. Resumes walking into--
Where Carter is back in bed covered in tubes. Virginia lies with Rachel on the bed next to him. Rachel is asleep.
How is he?
Quiet. I wasn’t sure if I should call you, I--
Of course. Please. Is there anything I can do for you? Are the boys--
We're fine. Really... He wanted me to give you this. She sits up and pulls the taped-together Bucket List out of her purse.
There’s a letter too. I was supposed to wait until... But then I thought--
--she’s never listened to me before, why let a coupl’a tumors get in the way. Edward sits down on the side of his bed.  105.
What’s with all the hair?
How they treating you?
Food still sucks.
I’ll talk to the owner.
I wouldn’t, I hear he’s a prick.
He definitely has his moments... Edward nods. It’s all under the bridge.
(holds the List) What was I going to do with this?
It isn’t finished.
It’s not a one man job.
It's going to have to be. Edward scans the remaining items. Stops on one of them.
No it doesn’t... I’1l be-- (heads for the door) Don’t go anywhere. Runs out. EXT. HOLCOMB’S OFFICE - NIGHT Holcomb’s packing up for the night when Edward enters, speaking on his cell phone.
I don’t care how, just get a hold of him and call me back. He snaps the phone shut and glares at Holcomb.  106.
Can he be moved without hurting him?
Well, technically yes, but--
I’m taking him out of here.
Edward walks with Holcomb trailing him. Thomas stands as he sees them.
Pull the car up front.
I cannot allow you to sneak him out again. I could be personally liable-- As Edward slams him into the wall.

Plain English. I’m taking my friend out of here and you’re coming with us. You've got ten minutes to pack what you need or I will personally ask Thomas to rearrange your kidneys. Thomas smiles at Holcomb who nods abruptly.
Edward enters just as Carter is standing out of bed with help from Virginia.
How fast can you get him dressed?
Why?
I can dress my own damn self. Where we going?
One more trip. (to Virginia) Can I talk to you? (to Carter) Pack it up. We’re not home yet.  107. He ushers Virginia out into the hallway.
The limo doors open and Thomas emerges along with Edward, Holcomb and the entire Chambers family. Carter is weak but shuffles along towards the waiting Gulfstream.
If you could step it up we’re kind of on a schedule.
I'll step it up when you tell me where we're going.
Roger.
Sorry dad. As he lifts his father into his arms and carries him towards the plane.
Boy, put me down. Whose side are you on!
(to Lee) Does he ever stop talking?
Only when he’s eating.
Well, that I can relate to.

Zipping between large warehouses. Carter sits in the back with Virginia. He’s blindfolded and bitching and wearing a new suit. Edward’s in the front next to the driver. The golf cart pulls to a stop next to a warehouse door. Virginia helps Carter out while Edward gets the door.
The doorway is curtained off with thick, sound-eating drapes. Virginia leads Carter inside.  108.
You're enjoying this, aren’t you? Muffled clapping is heard from the other side of the curtains. A man in a BASEBALL CAP pushes through an opening.
Great. We’re ready for you.
Who the hell’s he talking to?

And now our contestants entering the studio: a college professor from Gladwyne, Pennsylvania, Deenaz Olpadwala. Edward removes the blindfold and pushes Carter through the curtains. ON CARTER; As his eyes adjust then light up as a familiar theme plays.
The real deal, replete with a live studio audience.
Our second contestant.
How in the world did you--?
I had a couple million lying around.
A garage mechanic from Newark, New Jersey...
But that’s all you had--
So go earn it back.
Carter Chambers.
You son of a bitch.  109. He straightens his tie and walks purposefully towards his podium. Roger, Lee and Rachel cheer him on from the stands as he nervously takes his place.
The game is underway. ALEX TREBEK calls the clues...
This sophistic monk is often credited as one of the causes of the Russian Revolution. Carter hits the button but his timing is off.
Who is Rasputin?
Correct.
I’‘ll take Mad Men for two hundred.
An animated character with a predilection for tall headwear... Carter.
The Mad Hatter.
No... Sherman. SHERMAN, the bookish current champion clears his throat.
Who is the Mad Hatter?
Yes. Edward stands anxiously with Virginia.
Get it together. Virginia shushes him.
Mad Men for three-hundred.  110.
This King of England earned his maligned nickname in part by conversing with a tree he believed to be the King of Prussia.
Who is King George?
Can you be more specific?
Who is “Mad” King George the third.
Correct. Virginia grabs Edward. The Chambers kids cheer.
Carter takes control of the board.

I’1l take Mad Men for four-hundred, Alex. A SERIES OF CUTS; as Carter begins to run the board. His answers are quick and on the mark. The other contestants get an answer here and there but the game is clearly Carter’s to win. Roger, Lee and Rachel continue to cheer him on. Virginia's grip on Edward’s arm grows tighter and tighter until he winces.

Oh. Sorry. (Carter gets another answer) Go on, baby! She’s punches Edward’s arm in glee. The game continues. Carter is doing well but he’s beginning to tire. Sweat stains are visible on his collar. Edward now stands several feet away from Virginia.
Is he okay?
He'll be fine.  111. She applauds as he gets another correct answer.
The game is down to Final Jeopardy. The final category is on the board:
The category is World Monuments and the final clue is-- The clue is revealed...
(reading) This mughal emperor built the Taj Mahal to memorialize the death of his wife, Empress Mumtaz Mahal. Edward smiles as the Final Jeopardy theme plays.

It’s in the bag. His grin begins to subside as he watches Carter wipe a think band of sweat from his forehead. CARTER’S POV; is blurred as his hand slips on the pen. He closes his eyes to steady himself, but his vision is blurred even further.
Edward.

I see it. He starts circling the stage, crossing behind the cameras to get closer to the contestants. Carter scribbles loosely on the screen but drops the pen and falls just as Edward gets there to catch him. FADE TO WHITE. Voices are heard...
.-..-do our best, but it’s too far along.  112.
Anything you need.

head_text.subj: THE FACE OF A BEAUTIFUL WOMAN

text: Carter’s POV as Virginia stares down at him.
Hey, babe. Can you hear me all right?
(dazed) Wha- Where time is it? His face is paralyzed on one side. His head is shaved and heavily marked with surgery markers.
We're in the hospital. You had a stroke, but you’re gonna be fine.
Where’s Alex?
(looking) Who’s Alex?
He's probably sleeping. It’s almost midnight.
They’re taking you in for surgery in a minute.
Okay.
I’ll leave you two alone.
Wait. (to Virginia) My bag. She reaches for his overnight bag.  113.
Can you-- She opens it for him. He reaches inside and pulls out a sealed envelope and a folded slip of paper.
Got any of that coffee left?
I’m all out. I can see if there’s anywhere that sells it out here, but--
(smiles) Not if I was dying of thirst in the desert... Wanna know why?
“I'm sure you'll enlighten me.” Carter hands the paper to Edward.
Read.

(reading) Kopi Luwak is the world’s most expensive coffee, though, for some, it falls under the category of too good to be true. In the village where the beans are grown lives a breed of wild African tree-cats. The cats eat the beans, digest them, then... (a beat; he swallows) ...then defecate them out for the villagers to collect. It’s the gastric juices of the cat that give the coffee its unique flavor and absence of aftertaste... You’re shitting me?

Cats beat me to it. He bursts into weak laughter. Edward stares for a moment then starts to chuckle himself. Soon both men are laughing until tears stream down their cheeks. As he laughs, Edward's tears become gradually laced with grief as he hold’s Carter's wrist.
Still have the list?  114.

Of course. (pulls it out along with the red pen) There’s only a few left. Which one do you want to do next? Carter runs a finger down the items, until he reaches “LAUGH UNTIL I CRY.” He crosses it off shakily with the pen. Only four remain. His finger stops on the half finished “#11) GET BACK IN TOUCH” Edward sees this.
There's a difference between dying alone and living like you're already dead... Finish the list, Edward. He places the envelope atop the list.
Go home.
Edward emerges through the sliding doors. He wipes the tears flowing from his face, unsure of where to go.
As Holcomb enters, scrubbed for surgery, with several nurses.
We're ready. Carter reaches out for Virginia’s hand and presses it to his heart.
I’ll be here when you get back.
Forever’s just getting started. Her hand slips out of his as he’s wheeled out of the room.  115.

Edward loses himself in the raindrops sliding down the window as the plane readies for takeoff. He glances down at the envelope in his lap and turns it over. On the front is his name and address. He thinks a moment, steeling himself before he opens it.
Carter lies unconscious with a tube in his mouth as the surgeons do their work. In contrast to Edward, he looks completely at peace.
Dear Edward. It’s turning cold out here in Newark and the trees are like skeletons beneath the lamp posts. Winter’s almost upon us and despite what the doctors tell me, I know it will be my last.
Seen from the Hudson, the mandala of lights reflect like jewels in the water. Carter sits on the edge of a pier taking in the view...
You know how I love to tell stories so if you can spare a few minutes I think I’ve got a good one for you... He returns to the letter in his lap, and resumes writing...
There was an old farmer spent his life working the earth to give his family all the cares and comforts he’d never had.
Edward reads the words as Carter speaks them.  116.

One day the farmer fell sick and he called his sons to his bedside where he took up a bundle of sticks and said to his eldest son, "Show me that you can break it.” The son strained and strained, but with all his efforts was unable to break the bundle. Edward finishes the letter and wipes the tears from his cheeks. The flashing wing lights of the plane reflect the raindrop on the window indelibly onto his face.
Seen from above as Roger, Lee and Rachel lie in bed with their mother, clinging to her as she prays.
The other sons also tried, but none of them could break it. "Untie the bundle," said the farmer, "And each of you take a stick."
As Edward walks up the path to his daughter’s house. He knocks on the door without hesitation.

When they had done so, he called out to them, "Now, break them," and each stick was easily broken... The door opens revealing Emily. She’s surprised and her sleepy features harden instantly. Edward begins to talk.
No man is an island, my friend. We’re just not built that way.
Virginia scoops instant coffee into a styrofoam cup. She looks up as Holcomb appears at the other end of the hallway walking towards her. His face is unreadable.

You measure yourself by the people who measure themselves by you, and no matter how you battle the current--  117. EXT. EMILY’S HOUSE - DAWN Thomas leans against the limo, watching through the window as Carter and Emily speak. Her guard is still up, but she’s listening...
--our lives are streams flowing into the same river towards whatever heaven lies in the mist beyond the falls.
We can’t see Holcomb’s face or what he’s saying as he reaches Virginia, but her expression says it all. The coffee cup slips from her hands and lands at her feet, spilling onto the floor.

Find the joy in your life, Edward. Close your eyes and let the waters take you. INT. EMILY’S HOUSE - DAWN Edward shakes Emily’s hand goodbye. She’s not giving in, but it’s a start. He reaches for the front door just as a LITTLE GIRL, still half-asleep, comes out from the back bedroom. Edward is stunned.

Open your heart and listen to the mountain... He looks up at Emily who says something to the little girl. He crouches down as the girl walks right up to him and lays her head on his shoulder. His eyes are full as he looks up at Emily in amazement then slowly kisses his granddaughter’s head.
Carter's face is at peace. Virginia’s face comes into frame and kisses him softly. Her tears fall onto his eyelids and continue down his cheeks.
I promise you’ll be heard.

Virginia stands in the doorway, staring at her sleeping children. Rachel opens her eyes and looks at her mother.  118. EXT. EMILY’S HOUSE - DAWN Edward walks the path towards Thomas and the waiting limo.
We're a bundle of sticks, you and I, be it in this world or the one that follows. I will be forever grateful for the joy your life has brought to mine. Thomas opens the car door for him.
So that’s your daughter?
(emotional) Yup.
Pretty. Edward looks angry. Thomas waits for the rebuke. Instead, Edward pats him on the shoulder before climbing into the car. Thomas looks back at the house as the lights go out.
Edward pulls the list out of his pocket. With the red pen he crosses out: “KISS THE MOST BEAUTIFUL WOMAN IN THE WORLD.”
Your friend always... Carter. Edward lowers the window and looks out at the painted dawn sky as the limo drives away. He stares for several moments then closes his eyes and listens...
Good afternoon. My name is Edward Cole and I’m not much of a storyteller.
Edward is in his business suit again. His game face on.
I’m a business man, a good one. I run hospitals. (MORE)

We take sick people and make them well again. Sometimes we succeed and sometimes we fail, but we’re getting better at it every day... I started out with nothing but cold ambition, and over the years my company grew until I had everything I ever wanted... I know now that-- I know now that I was never a wealthy man until my best friend came into my life...and from this incredible turnout, it only verifies the fact that Carter was truly the richest man I know. CAMERA TRACKS until we’re behind Edward revealing his audience of nearly a THOUSAND MOURNERS filling every last inch of the room including Carter’s family who sit in the front row. Familiar faces in the crowd include Manny, Holcomb, Nurse Shing, parents and players of the soccer team, etc.

I don’t know what most people say at these things, so I’1l just tell you what I think Carter would want you to know. He’s dead and I still can’t shut him up... He loved his children more than his own heart. He loved his wife more than his own soul. He took the long way home but he made it back and you took him in and made him whole again and you will never know how grateful he was. His eyes move from the family to Thomas who stands against the wall with Emily and her daughter.

(taking out the Bucket List) We saw the world together. Pretty amazing when you think that only nine months ago we were strangers... He saved my life, and he knew it before I did. With the pen, he crosses out: “HELP A COMPLETE STRANGER FOR THE GOOD.” Beneath it, the last remaining task lies unfulfilled: “LISTEN TO THE MOUNTAIN AND BE HEARD.” Slowly, the words on the page--
As the climber from the opening scene finally arrives at the peak.

Carter gave me a book once. It was about a man who knew a thing or two about the world. The climber walks over to a flat stone and lifts it onto its side. He removes his gloves revealing a wedding ring on his left hand. EDWARD (V.O.) (CONT’D) The man said: “Learn as if you were going to live forever. Live as if you were going to die tomorrow.” His hands lift to his face, removing the oxygen mask and hood revealing THOMAS. He reaches down and lifts A FROZEN CHOCK FULL O’ NUTS CAN from its resting place in the hole beneath the rock. He wipes off a section of frost with his thumb revealing: A PHOTOGRAPH taped to the can -- Carter and Virginia at their second wedding surrounded by their family. Thomas sets the can on the snow then opens his backpack and reaches down to the bottom-- EDWARD (V.O.) (CONT’D) Tomorrow comes for all of us. --and removes A SECOND CHOCK FULL 0’ NUTS CAN which he places on the ground next to the first. EDWARD (V.O.) (CONT’D) It’s what we do in-between that makes us who we are. CLOSE ON A NEWER PHOTOGRAPH; taped to the second coffee can. It’s Edward. He’s old and grey.

Edward Perriman Cole died in May. It was a Sunday, in the afternoon, and there wasn’t a cloud in the sky... CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal that he’s closely surrounded by Thomas, Emily and their THREE CHILDREN, hands intertwined with--  121. --Carter’s grandchildren, each of whom stands with their parents and Virginia. One family. Edward is smiling like we’ve never seen.

He was seventy-nine years old. Finally, Thomas deposits both cans into the hole beneath the rock. CARTER (V.O.) (CONT’D) Even now, I can’t claim to understand the measure of a life, but I can tell you this... Thomas replaces the rock over the coffee cans.

I know that when he died his eyes were closed, and his heart was open... I know that he could hear the mountain... THE CAMERA lingers on the rock for a moment then tilts up to reveal the breathtaking view of the entire world below. CARTER (V.O.) (CONT’D) And I know the mountain heard him in return. THE END.
